274.title: Inverse Kinematics (IK)
274.content: Understanding the IK system that automatically positions joints to achieve natural poses.

276.title: Overview
276.content: IK is implemented for both arms and legs using Unity’s RigBuilder and Two Bone IK Constraint. Within the IK system, the target (item at the end of the limb) and hint objects (item that that elbow points towards) are required to ensure the system is fully working. However, the current IK setup simply sets the hint weights very low, so the hints don’t affect the IK much. “Currently, the settings used in the above sets the value of the Hint Weight to be low to ensure that when we use our rotation gizmo or make changes to posekun without the IK system, these changes are retained instead of being overridden. However, take note that the lower the hint weight, the lesser the arm or leg will bend towards the hint object, which may lead to less realistic limb movement.” - January 2025 Documentation YouTube video with the same IK setup: Inverse Kinematics Unity Tutorial in 3 minutes .

277.title: Disabling / Enabling IK
277.content: RigBuilder must be enabled for IK to function. However, it prevents FK (directly rotating the joint). Thus, RigBuilder component is disabled, and only enabled when the user is holding down the mouse on a movable IK target (the hands and feet joints).

285.title: Joint Structure

286.title: Overview
286.content: The joint structure is based on that of the FBX model (Bodykun). The current Bodykun has joints that are named in Japanese using the MMD format. Under each (movable) joint, there is a child with the English name, that contains a collider + the scripts needed such as PoseLoader, etc.

It defines how bones are connected, how they move in relation to each other, and provides the foundation for realistic human pose creation.

Purpose: Core body movement and posture . | Hip/Root: Foundation joint for entire character | Spine: Lower back flexibility | Chest: Upper torso rotation and bending | Neck: Head orientation support | Head: Final orientation point | . Arm Chains (Left/Right) . Purpose: Upper limb manipulation . | Shoulder: Arm attachment and lifting | Upper Arm: Major arm rotation | Elbow: Arm bending joint | Forearm: Wrist rotation support | Wrist: Hand attachment point | Hand: Finger base connection | . 297.title: Layers and Tags
297.content: Unity’s layer and tag system organization for efficient rendering and object management.

298.title: Overview
298.content: Since the previous design of the bodykun was in editor rather than during Runtime initialisation, there are a few places where layers and tags are necessary to function. This will be a simple introduction of these areas.

299.title: Introduction to Current Layers and Tags
299.content: Layers: . Skeleton: Posekun objects will be added to this layer so that it can be rendered using the posekunCamera IKJoints: used for all IK target objects in the Rig HandTransform: used in RestrictionAndHandAnimation scene. All finger joint GameObjects are assigned to this layer. This layer is utilized to disable rotation gizmo for the finger object. If you want to tune the finger joints with transform gizmo, set their layer to default. Tags: . Within this unity project, the above tags have been added for use if necessary. Currently, the only tags that are utilized during runtime as checking conditions are leftFingers and rightFingers. They are used in Drawlimb and DrawPosekun in order to change the way finger joints are drawn. For the sake of convenience when initialising bodykun during runtime(and the fact that right and left are the same), all of the hand joints inside Structure.isFinger are tagged as “leftFingers”.

300.title: Joint Selection:
300.content: Within the TransformGizmo script, there is a function GetTarget() which will check for inputs on the layers specified in the SelectionMask property. If the script detects a touch on a joint (a collider is required for touch detection), we will set that joint to be the joint to apply the rotation gizmo to. Ensure that Layer is set to those in the Selection Mask.

301.title: Camera rendering objects:
301.content: Ensure that the Culling Mask property of the mainCamera includes all layers that we want to render into the scene. If the layer is not added, the camera will not render objects on that layer. However, as seen in the above image, the Skeleton layer is not selected in the culling mask for the main camera. This is because all objects in the skeleton layer are instead rendered on a separate camera. As seen, posekunCamera is the one responsible for rendering posekun onto the scene. The reason why there are 2 cameras used in this setup is to ensure that posekun will always render on top of other objects. This is especially important since bodykun needs to be displayed on screen with posekun as well. In the event that more objects need to be rendered into the scene at different depths, this camera setup can be replicated and modified to easily set the render order.
